repnme.cdata!: Iraq - Regional Health Emergency Response Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Regional Health
            Emergency Response Project for Iraq were as follows: overall
            outcome was moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was substantial, and both the Bank and the Borrower
            performance were moderately satisfactory. The important
            project lessons learned were: (1) in uncertain,
            post-conflict and low capacity environments keep the project
            simple and focused on the main development outcome. (2)
            Proactive supervision and hands-on support are paramount for
            success in low capacity environments. (3) In conflict or
            post-conflict projects, flexibility in adjusting project
            content during implementation is advisable. (4) Planning and
            investing for sustainability should be embedded in the
            project design. (5) Training and capacity building are
            mandatory but not enough for acquiring specialized technical
            expertise. (6) Dedicated expertise is still needed after
            project completion to ensure sustainability. (7) Solid
            technical knowledge and skills and management expertise are
            a sine qua non in the selection process of the
            implementation agencies for successful project preparation
            and implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Iraq - Regional Health Emergency Response
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Regional Health Emergency Response Project for Iraq is to
            assist the Kurdistan Regional Government to build capacity
            in the establishment of rapid, coordinated and effective
            response services to health emergencies, including those
            resulting from acts of violence, accidents, or natural
            disasters. This is a second level restructuring to include
            an additional method of procurement to the grant agreement
            for the project as per the request of the Ministry of Health
            of the Regional Government of Kurdistan (KRG MOH) dated
            January 4, 2012. The original grant for the above project
            was approved on June 19, 2008 for US$8.7 million, with
            additional financing for US$4.5 million approved on June 30,
            2010. The project is at 80 percent physical completion, with
            the disbursement level at 82 percent. The project is rated
            as moderately satisfactory, with the near completion and
            functionality of the Emergency Coordination Centers (ECCs),
            the installation of the CAD/AVL (emergency tracking system),
            and the installation of radio towers. All blood banks have
            been completed, equipped, and is operational, except for the
            Erbil Blood Bank which has settlement cracks in the facility
            which need to be remedied prior to being operational. Data
            for collection and use of blood for emergency purposes is
            currently being collected. Other project data such as
            response time using the new system and registration of
            incoming calls, will be collected in February 2012 once the
            Emergency Coordination Centers (ECCs) are operational.

            Response Project : restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Iraq - Regional Health Emergency Response
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Regional Health Emergency Response Project is to assist the
            Kurdistan regional government to build capacity in the
            establishment of rapid, coordinated and effective response
            services to health emergencies, including those resulting
            from acts of violence, accidents, or natural disasters. This
            is a level two restructuring for a six-month extension of
            the project, which has a current closing date of December
            31, 2011 and therefore it is to extend the closing date to
            June 30, 2012. This will be the second extension of the
            project. The extension has been assessed to be needed to
            complete all remaining project activities, by which the
            project objectives will be met within the requested
            six-month period.
